item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Biden Joins Europe in Punishing Russia With Sanctions
item.description: Washington and its allies called the Kremlin’s recognition of two separatist regions a blunt defiance of international law that risks war. Western officials said Russian troops have entered eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times

item.title: As French Elections Loom, Macron Tries to Strike a Balance
item.description: The news media calls the French president “Jupiter,” the king of the gods, but he is trying to show a more human face. Will it soften his image?
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Sarahbeth Maney/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, center left, at an Armistice Day event in Paris in November. The power of the presidency in the country has little equivalent in other Western democracies.

item.title: Ukraine Enclaves Long Steeped in Conflict Face New Peril
item.description: A decision by Russia to recognize two separatist territories and order in troops raises the risks of intensified fighting in an already fraught region where violence has defined life for nearly a decade.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Viktoria Gudyatskaya and her daughter Svetlana, 14, boarding a train to Kyiv in Severodonetsk, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: In Kyiv, a Soldier’s Funeral and Vows of Defiance
item.description: Ukrainians have been preparing for a possible military escalation by Russia for months. They were somber but largely defiant.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Brendan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral on Tuesday for Capt. Anton Sidorov, a 35-year-old Ukrainian intelligence officer killed three days earlier while serving on the front line in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Piece by Piece, Russia’s Rationale for a Ukraine Invasion Is Put in Place
item.description: Theatrical meetings and dubious battlefield reports have shaped the Kremlin’s narrative that war is being pushed on it by a United States determined to destroy Russia.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: People who fled from separatist territory in eastern Ukraine following Russian claims about an attack by Ukraine watching Mr. Putin speak on Monday night.

item.title: Canada Ends Its Freeze on Hundreds of Accounts Tied to Protests
item.description: After a court denied bail to one arrested protest organizer, the government said it was winding up its pursuit of people involved in the unrest.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers making arrests at the trucker protest in Ottawa on Friday.

item.title: Colombia Decriminalizes Abortion, Bolstering Trend Across Region
item.description: The court’s decision follows years of organizing by women across Latin America for greater protections and more rights, and significant shifts in the region’s legal landscape.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abortion rights supporters celebrating in front of Colombia’s Constitutional Court during the ruling in favor of decriminalizing abortion up to 24 weeks gestation, in Bogotá on Monday.

item.title: To Preserve Its Own Stability, Pakistan Must Stabilize Afghanistan First
item.description: Analysts say that the Taliban takeover has sparked a spike in terror attacks that have put the Pakistani government in a difficult position as it tries to support Afghanistan’s new government.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:credit: Danial Shah/Getty Images
item.media:description: Taliban fighters at the Torkham crossing as seen from the Pakistani side, last August.

item.title: Europe Sanctions Russia Over Ukraine Crisis, Coordinating Squeeze With the U.S.
item.description: The European Union, acting in tandem with the United States and Britain, hopes to restrain Moscow by keeping bigger penalties in reserve.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Central Moscow, with Red Square in the background, last year. In drawing up penalties, Western leaders must decide whether President Vladimir V. Putin’s actions amount to a further Russian invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: For Ukraine’s Jews, the Threat of War Stirs Memories of Past Horrors
item.description: In Odessa, Jewish leaders are preparing for the worst: hiring security guards, scoping out bomb shelters and making plans to evacuate if Russia invades the country.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prayer services following shabbat at the Great Choral Synagogue in Odessa, Ukraine.

item.title: ‘Dark Money’ Suddenly Dominates Australia’s Election
item.description: Chinese financing, unreported donations, payouts from coal barons: The new political season is shining an unaccustomed light on a culture of opacity.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Lukas Coch/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison, left, and Anthony Albanese, the opposition leader, at the House of Representatives in Canberra, Australia.

item.title: Covid Live Updates: Most N.Y. Voters in Poll Want More Data Before School Mask Mandate Ends
item.description: As England lifts rules, high-risk people fear more isolation. Hong Kong will enforce mass testing as cases soar. As many U.S. states move to end mask mandates, Hawaii and Puerto Rico remain outliers.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Old San Juan, Puerto Rico, in January. Puerto Rico, the largest U.S. territory, has yet to announce any changes to its island-wide mask mandate.

item.title: Japan Wants to Showcase Gold Mines’ History. Just Not All of It.
item.description: A bid for a UNESCO World Heritage designation is the latest flash point between Japan and South Korea over Japanese colonial abuses during World War II.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gold and silver mine on Sado Island, Japan. Mines on the island once supplied the shoguns of Japan with precious metals.

item.title: U.S. and Allies Impose Sanctions on Russia as Biden Condemns ‘Invasion’ of Ukraine
item.description: President Biden warned President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia that more sanctions would follow if he did not withdraw his forces and engage in diplomatic efforts to resolve the crisis.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Richard Pérez-Peña, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Parents said goodbye to their children in Severodonetsk, eastern Ukraine, on Tuesday, after President Vladimir V. Putin recognized separatist areas of the country.

item.title: Will Biden’s Sanctions Halt a Russian Invasion of Ukraine?
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin has learned from earlier U.S.-led sanctions, and his allies could benefit from a more isolated Russia.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin has had years to make his country’s $1.5 trillion economy more insular so that parts of Russia would be shielded from tough penalties.

item.title: UN Leader Deepens Criticism of Russia Over Ukraine Crisis
item.description: António Guterres said Ukraine’s sovereign territory had been violated, and he rejected Vladimir Putin’s description of Russian troops as peacekeepers.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:credit: Jason Szenes/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: António Guterres, the secretary general of the United Nations, at the U.N. headquarters in New York on Tuesday.

item.title: Here Is a Transcript of President Biden’s Speech on Russia
item.description: Here is a lightly edited transcript of the president’s speech announcing new sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden at the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Refers to Russian Aggression Toward Ukraine as ‘Genius’
item.description: In a radio interview, the former president also described Russian troops along the Ukrainian border as peacekeepers.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Osaka, Japan, in 2019.

item.title: Russia’s Moves in Ukraine Unsettle Energy Companies and Prices
item.description: Oil and gas prices are up, and Western energy giants with operations and investments in Russia could find it harder to keep doing business there.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss and Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: A power station in eastern Ukraine was heavily bombed on Tuesday. Oil prices quickly jumped to nearly $100 a barrel after reports that Russian troops had entered Ukrainian separatist territories.

item.title: The Limits of a Europe Whole and Free
item.description: Vladimir Putin sets down a marker in Ukraine. Does the West have the means to stop him?
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian self-propelled howitzers Msta-S are loaded onto a train car at the station outside Taganrog, Russia, on Tuesday.

item.title: The West Sanctions Russia
item.description: President Biden condemned what he called the “beginning of a Russian invasion of Ukraine.”
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden spoke on Tuesday about tensions between Russia and Ukraine.

item.title: Global Tours Were Key for Orchestras. Then the Pandemic Hit.
item.description: Two years after the coronavirus paralyzed classical music, ensembles are again returning to the global stage. But they face significant challenges.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández

item.title: Biden Calls Putin’s Actions ‘Beginning of a Russian Invasion of Ukraine'
item.description: President Biden condemned President Vladimir V. Putin for his aggression against Ukraine, saying the new sanctions cut off Russia from Western finance.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden speaking at the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: Sanctions on Russia pose new threat to a fragile global economy.
item.description: Armed conflict could exacerbate supply chain disruptions and drive food, gas and other prices higher.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier at a frontline position in Novozvanivka, in the region of Luhansk, on Monday.

item.title: Three key decisions have shaped Biden’s handling of the Ukraine crisis.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Sarahbeth Maney/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden in Washington last week.

item.title: White House Weighs How Hard to Hit Putin With Sanctions
item.description: Early indications suggested the Biden administration would hold some punishments back in hopes of preventing a broader attack.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest in support of Ukraine outside the White House on Sunday.

item.title: US Troops in Poland Brace for Possible Ukrainian Evacuees.
item.description: The Biden administration has repeatedly said U.S. troops will not fight in Ukraine or rescue Americans trapped there by a Russian attack.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Bryan Woolston/Reuters
item.media:description: U.S. soldiers at a camp near the Polish border with Ukraine on Monday.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth Cancels All Virtual Engagements as She Battles Covid
item.description: The queen will “continue with light duties,” Buckingham Palace said, and “further engagements over the coming week will be decided upon nearer the time.”
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Chris Jackson Collection, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II, center, last year. On Sunday, she became one of the world’s most prominent figures to battle the virus.

item.title: Hong Kong Will Require Its Residents to Get Tested in March
item.description: Residents will have to take three tests over a short period, starting in March.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Kin Cheung/Associated Press
item.media:description: Lining up to get tested for the coronavirus at a temporary testing center in Hong Kong on Tuesday.

item.title: The European Union Drafts a Set of Sanctions Against Russia
item.description: The diplomats said the draft included 27 individuals and entities, including political, military, business and financial entities.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Moscow this month.

item.title: The Ginni Thomas Question
item.description: We have a Times investigation of Ginni and Clarence Thomas — as well as the latest news from Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer/Getty Images
item.media:description: Ginni Thomas at the Heritage Foundation.

item.title: A Victorian graveyard’s leafy pathways have taken on new meaning for some during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia

item.title: Ukraine’s president says his country is committed to peace but ‘ready for everything.’
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy and Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine addressing the nation in a live broadcast in Kyiv early Tuesday.

item.title: If You Haven’t Thought About Coronavirus in Animals, You Should
item.description: With the virus widespread in white-tailed deer, scientists wonder which animals might be next.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Imbler and Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Marine Buffard

item.title: The conflict’s economic consequences are likely to threaten global growth.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen, Jack Ewing and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trucks carrying wheat at a port in Mykolaiv, Ukraine. Combined, Russia and Ukraine account for nearly a quarter of global wheat exports.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Russia orders troops into Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian armored vehicles on Monday near Rostov-on-Don, a Russian city 60 miles from Ukraine.

item.title: U.S. diplomatic staff relocate from Ukraine to Poland.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.S. Embassy in Kyiv the day after the United States announced it was relocating its diplomatic staff.

item.title: Putin Calls Ukrainian Statehood a Fiction. History Suggests Otherwise.
item.description: In a speech, President Vladimir V. Putin bent Ukraine’s complex history into his own version that served as a justification for his cleaving off more of its territory.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Maria Varenikova and Rick Gladstone
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: People in Odessa on Sunday commemorated protesters killed in 2014 by paramilitary police forces in Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: U.S. Offers Limited Initial Response to Russia as It Weighs Stiffer Sanctions
item.description: President Biden faces the challenge of maintaining unity with allies as he seeks to balance deterrence and punishment in dealing with President Vladimir Putin of Russia.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Alexei Nikolsky
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia signing documents recognizing the independence of separatist regions in eastern Ukraine on Monday. He then ordered Russian troops into those areas.

item.title: Putin Orders Forces to Russia-Backed Ukraine Regions
item.description: The moves by the Russian leader were his most blatant yet in a confrontation with the West that threatens to escalate into the biggest military action in Europe since World War II.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Valerie Hopkins and Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kristina Makarenko, 24, sitting in a shelter with her two-year-old son, Anton, after hearing news that more shelling might be imminent Monday in the eastern Ukrainian village of Vrubivka.

item.title: Israel Says Police Didn’t Hack Civilians Without Court Approval
item.description: An official investigation refuted claims that the police had illegally hacked dozens of civilians using spyware from NSO Group, an Israeli company that has long attracted global scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Menahem Kahana/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The NSO Group logo on a wall of a building next to one of the company’s branches in southern Israel.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Putin Recognizes Separatists in Ukraine
item.description: Western officials warn that Russia is paving a path toward war.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

item.title: Highlights From Putin's Address on Breakaway Regions in Ukraine
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin said he would recognize the independence of two Russia-backed territories in eastern Ukraine. Here are highlights from his 40-minute speech.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Anatoly Maltsev/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A woman in St. Petersburg, Russia, watching President Vladimir Putin address the nation on Monday.

item.title: On the ground: A column of Russian vehicles, and soldiers without insignia.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A column of Russian armored vehicles, military trucks and supply units about 60 miles away from the border with Ukraine on Monday.

item.title: In Photos: Eastern Ukraine on Monday.
Boris Johnson warns that Russia is planning the biggest war in Europe since 1945.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian and Belarusian soldiers during joint exercises near Baranovichi, Belarus, on Saturday.

item.title: Paul Farmer, Pioneer of Global Health, Dies at 62
item.description: As a medical student, Dr. Farmer decided to build a clinic in Haiti. It grew into a vast network serving some of the world’s poorest communities.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry and Alex Traub
item.category: Mountains Beyond Mountains: The Quest of Dr. Paul Farmer, a Man Who Would Cure the World (Book)
item.media:credit: Angel Franco/The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Paul Farmer speaking with an H.I.V. patient, Altagrace Cenatus, at a Partners in Health hospital in Haiti in 2003. He worked to provide quality health care to some of the poorest people in the world.

item.title: Why Donetsk and Luhansk, in Donbas Region, Matter in Ukraine
item.description: The act of recognition is fraught with meaning because the borders claimed by the Russia-backed leaders of the two breakaway regions extend into space controlled by the Ukrainian army.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman at the border crossing between Russia and the separatist Donetsk People’s Republic in Avilo-Uspenka, Russia, on Saturday.

item.title: U.S. Troops in Poland Brace for Possible Ukrainian Evacuees
item.description: Tens of thousands of people, including Americans, could flee across the border if Russia launches a full invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Bryan Woolston/Reuters
item.media:description: U.S. Army soldiers in the 82nd Airborne Division in Poland near the Ukranian border on Monday.

item.title: In an Uneven Fight With China, Lithuania's Brand Becomes Toxic
item.description: After Lithuania dared to seek closer ties with Taiwan, China cut off trade — even blocking imports of products from other countries with Lithuanian parts.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Andrej Vasilenko for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brolis Group, a chip maker in Lithuania, recently scrapped plans to build a $50 million factory at home, mindful that foreign customers want to avoid ending up on China’s blacklist.

item.title: Got a Covid Booster? You Probably Won’t Need Another for a Long Time
item.description: A flurry of new studies suggests that several parts of the immune system can mount a sustained, potent response to any coronavirus variant.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Dr. Klaus Boller/Science Source
item.media:description: A colored transmission electron micrograph of a T cell. Antibodies are relatively easy to study, whereas analyzing immune cells requires blood, skill, special equipment and lots of time.

item.title: U.S. still sees an invasion as imminent, dimming hopes for a Biden-Putin summit.
item.description: Vladimir Putin ratcheted up tensions further Monday, announcing that he would recognize two breakaway Ukrainian regions as independent states.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, David E. Sanger and Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian army frontline position in Krymske, in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: 21uk
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian demonstrators protesting against Russia outside the White House on Sunday.

item.title: Putin says Russia will decide on Monday whether to recognize breakaway regions.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Sputnik/Via Reuters
item.media:description: Russian President Vladimir V. Putin chairing a meeting with members of the Security Council in Moscow on Monday.
